content.description: Sit start on a low, sharp double-crimp below the overhang, and move up to the left or right onto decent crimps and sidepulls.  Pull out of the overhang to the slab face on good crimps.  From here, climb the final 10 feet to the top on easy jugs.  See pg. 165, picture B8 in Croft and Lewis's "Bishop Area Rock Climbs".
content.protection: Pad, spotter.  Be especially careful to cover the boulder to the immediate left with a small pad or some thick clothing, as it would be *very* easy to blow the first move and hit your head on this.  If you possess the self-assuredness and style, heck, just do a Sherman the Vermin and wear your helmet...
content.location: On Girl Rock, at the left hand side of the Northeast face, immediately right of a 2-ft-high boulder.

content.description: Start from the high left facing flake on the arete and follow flakes up and right along the arete to a topout at the high point.
content.location: This problem follows the arete on the left side of the uphill face of the East Boulder of the pair from a high start.

content.description: Sit start on an excellent low juggy rail, and move left to another excellent jug.  From here, find good small feet, and move up to sharp crimps, then a slabby topout on juggy patina.  See pg. 165, picture B8 in Croft and Lewis's "Bishop Area Rock Climbs" (problem is slightly to left of line indicated in image.)
content.location: On Girl Rock, at the obvious chalked up low rail/jugs in the middle of the Northeast face, to the immediate left of the large patch of patina.
